slides.title: Welcome to Roles and Permissions
slides.notes: Introduction to the roles and permissions topic in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Welcome to our deep dive into Roles and Permissions in Guidewire PolicyCenter. This lesson is crucial as it forms the backbone of how access and capabilities are managed within the system. Understanding this will help you configure and customize PolicyCenter to meet your organization's security requirements effectively. Let's explore how permissions are structured and how you can leverage them for robust access control.
slides.ocrText: Roles and Permissions

slides.title: Understanding Access in PolicyCenter
slides.notes: Focus on how access is fundamentally managed through permissions in PolicyCenter.
slides.narration: Access in PolicyCenter is fundamentally managed through a set of permissions that define what users can and cannot do. This robust access control system ensures that users only perform actions relevant to their roles, enhancing both security and efficiency. As developers, we often customize these permissions to align with the unique needs of the business, ensuring the right balance between flexibility and control.

slides.title: Security in PolicyCenter
slides.originalNotes:
Security in PolicyCenter
PolicyCenter Security makes the application flexible, robust, and keeps information protected. The PolicyCenter default application contains a set of roles that perform the most organizations’ policy tasks. To perform these tasks, a user must be assigned a role with the appropriate permissions. In the base configuration, the Superuser role is granted all permissions and is responsible for granting permissions to other roles. Once the roles are configured, each PolicyCenter user is assigned aspecific role relating to their assigned tasks. Note: Although Superuser has all permissions in the base configuration, that ability could change if a customer adds custom permissions

slides.title: Permissions Influence Access
slides.originalNotes:
Permissions can influence access
The list of abilities in the slide is a general way of viewing permissions, not an official categorization. Some permissions map directly to one of the listed functions. For example, there are "view accounts" and "view audit“ permissions. Other permissionsmap indirectly to the listed functions. For example, there are"bind policy change" and"bind submission" permissions, both are"act on" permissions. All permissions change the user experience in one of two ways:
A permission controls whether an aspect of the user interface is visible. For example, users without the View Team permission will not see the Team tab, whereas users with this permission see the tab.
A permission controls whether a user succeeds (or fails) a given task. For example, if a user attempts to bind a submission or policy change, the binding fails. The user can save a draft, and a user with the bind submission or bind policy change permission can successfully perform the task.

slides.title: Create Object Permissions
slides.originalNotes:
Create object permissions
PolicyCenter prevents users from a disallowed action by failing to display the particular button or menu item. There may be cases where a permission is not applied to a menu item or button, but to a back-end function call. In such cases, PolicyCenter may display a permission restriction error message. For example, some Ul components do not have permission restrictions. A user without an assigned role may see those IJI components but cannot proceed due to restrictions applied at the function call level. In the slide example:
Alice Applegate is an underwriter with Create documents and Create a New Submission permissions. When she wants to create a document, she clicks on the Actions menu and proceeds create using the New Document menu item. She gets additional submenu options to create a new document by Linking to an existing document or Create a new document from a template. She can create new submissions from the menu.
Adam Auditor is an auditor and does not have access to the Actions menu or the menu item New Submission.
 Permission restriction behavior can be configured in PolicyCenter application.
 Note: Some of the examples in this lesson have been created for training purposes only and may not be available in sample data.

slides.title: Permissions Determined at Login
slides.originalNotes:
A user's permissions are determined during login
When an end user attempts to log in, the following occurs:
The user supplies a username and password to PolicyCenter via the login page.
PolicyCenter queries its database to authenticate the user and determine which permissions are assigned to the user and the user's start page- In the base product, authentication is managed through the PolicyCenter database, which stores usernames and passwords in a database table. The system can also be configured to authenticate against an existing user domain structure. Permissions determine which screens the user can access and which actions the user can perform. The startup view is the first page rendered after log in.
 PolicyCenter authenticates the user.
 PolicyCenter renders the appropriate startup view with permissions appropriate for that user.

Note: The Superuser log in (csu") is exempt from permission checks. This user is set as a power user in config.xml,and can inherently do everything in the application. This login would not be given to a real user in a PolicyCenter production environment, but it is useful during development.

slides.title: Role Configuration
slides.originalNotes:
Roles
There are no absolute rules regarding how the permission/role structure must be built to accommodate users with varying access levels. For example, if underwriters are able to do everything an underwriter assistant can do, as well as some underwriter-only tasks, then:
You could create the Underwriter role with the permissions of the Underwriter Assistant role plus additional permissions.
You could create the Underwriter role with only the additional permissions that Underwriter Assistants do not have.

Roles have permissions that map to a job function. For example, the producer role contains permissions appropriate for someone who is a producer. This role might create submissions or edit accounts permissions, but it would not have the create users or issue submissions permissions. Similarly, a producer clerical role might only create submissions and not edit accounts. You can have at least one or more roles and are granted all of the permissions contained in any roles that are assigned. Roles provide the basic security that governs which actions can be used within PolicyCenter.

slides.title: Mapping Roles to Users
slides.originalNotes:
Mapping roles to users
In the slide example:
Dennis Right is an underwriter assistant and has all the permissions of an underwriter assistant through the underwriter assistant role.
Bruce Baker is an underwriter and has all the permissions of an undewriter through the underwriter role.
Rick Ralston is an underwriting supervisor and has all the permissions of a underwriting supervisor. He has both the Underwriter role and the Supervisor role. (Presumably, the Supervisor role does not contain all permissions normally associated to an underwriter.)

PolicyCenter permissions grant access to perform an action. Unlike the permission structure of other systems, PolicyCenter does not have permissions that specifically deny a person’s actionable abilities. The only way to prevent someone from having a given permission is not to assign them any roles with that permission. Roles are cumulative; a user gets all of the permissions associated with one or more roles that they have been assigned.

slides.title: Producer Code Security
slides.originalNotes:
Access for users with producer code security on
Users for whom Producer Code Security is set to Yes can only use their role permissions against policies that have a matching producer code. Only the producer
code permissions that match can be used against a policy, even if the user has a larger set of permissions available through their user roles. Both producer code and user role permissions must match for the user to gain access.

In this example, the user can access the policy because of matching producer code. The user has the Edit Policy Term permission in the user role, but the permission is not in the producer code's role. Therefore, the user cannot edit the policy term on the policy.

This ensures that even if a user has broader permissions, they can only apply them to relevant policies, enhancing security and maintaining organizational boundaries.

slides.title: Creating a New Role
slides.originalNotes:
Creating a new role
Every user belongs to an organization which can be the carrier's organization or an external organization(i.e- agency). Internal and extemal users and groups can be assigned producer codes. External users may only be assigned producer codes from their organization, but internal users may have external producer codes explicitly assigned. The user must specify whether this role is internal or external since the permissions and accessibility are dependent upon the user's organization type. The user and producer codes added to this role will be determined based on this information. Similarly, producer codes that belong to this organization can only be added for this role.
